Award.AwardTitle: Ohio Region Cybersecurity Technician Training Pipeline

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Keeping computers and information systems secure is a major challenge. Business, industry, and government need well-prepared technicians who can prevent, detect, and investigate cybersecurity breaches, and the growth of cyber-threats has created a need for many more workers who have appropriate, specific knowledge and skills. Many key companies in the Ohio region are finding it difficult to locate skilled cybersecurity technicians. In response to this need, Columbus State Community College, Franklin University, a consortium of technology-focused area high schools, and regional cybersecurity companies are collaborating to develop a comprehensive "2 + 2 + 2" Cybersecurity Technician Training Pipeline. This program will target high school graduates, college-aged students, adult learners, and incumbent workers and will include multiple entry and exit points for these students and stackable certificates that lead to entry-level, mid-level, and management-level cybersecurity careers.

The goal of the project is to increase the supply of qualified cybersecurity professionals for industry and government. Major activities include:
(1) Developing and implementing a 60 credit-hour Associate of Applied Science (AAS) degree and related academic certificates in cybersecurity at Columbus State Community College, which will prepare high school graduates and incumbent IT and non-IT workers to obtain the (ISC)2 Systems Security Certified Practitioner (SSCP) certification.
(2) Conducting workshops for high school teachers and establishing a pre-college program for regional high schools, which will serve as the first link in a "2 + 2 + 2" educational pathway in cybersecurity.
(3) Establishing a model articulation agreement with Franklin University, which will serve as the final link in the "2 + 2 + 2" pathway, allowing AAS graduates from Columbus State to transfer seamlessly into a BS degree program in cybersecurity.
Many components of the new curriculum, as well as the professional development activities for faculty, will draw on resources offered by the National CyberWatch Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CYBER Project Outcomes Report

Through the Ohio Region Cybersecurity Technician Training Pipeline (CYBER) program, Columbus State Community College developed an accredited cybersecurity program in collaboration with industry leaders to increase the pipeline of cybersecurity professionals for industry and government employers. The 2+2+2 model pathway provides students with multiple entry and exit points through dual enrollment opportunities, a robust Cybersecurity Associate of Applied Science track at Columbus State, and seamless articulation to Franklin University to pursue a Bachelor's of Science in Cybersecurity. This flexible career path in cybersecurity benefits students and employers by addressing the shifting needs of industry while accommodating the diverse interests and experiences of students and incumbent workers. Additionally, regional industry leaders had extensive input in the development of the Cybersecurity Associate of Applied Science (AAS) degree program by participating in a job skills analysis that identified key skills cybersecurity professionals need in the workplace. This ensures that students are being equipped to make an immediate impact in the workforce upon graduating from Columbus State's Cybersecurity program.

Key accomplishments of the CYBER program include:

1) The creation of a Cybersecurity AAS track at Columbus State that achieved accreditation as a National Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense Education (CAE-CDE) from the National Security Agency and the Department of Homeland Security. The program had 177 active students in the Spring 2019 semester and experienced a 77% growth in just two years since its official launch. 

2) The expansion of dual enrollment opportunities for high school students interested in cybersecurity to provide career exploration and accessibility to affordable pathways to post-secondary education. 34 Cybersecurity students from 20 local high schools took advantage of College Credit Plus earning college credits towards their Cybersecurity AAS while in high school.

3) The development of an articulation agreement between Columbus State and Franklin University to provide students with an opportunity to transfer seamlessly to pursue their education with a Bachelor's of Science in Cybersecurity.

4) The creation of six cybersecurity awareness modules called Building a Secure Future for the Columbus State community and general public. These modules introduce cybersecurity fundamental concepts and provide best practices for protecting digital identities. The modules have been integrated into staff and student orientations to create an environment of security at Columbus State. The Building a Secure Future modules can be found at https://www.cscc.edu/academics/departments/computer-it/cybersecurity/awareness-practices.shtml.

The Ohio Region Cybersecurity Technician Training Pipeline program at Columbus State has been influential in developing a successful Cybersecurity Associate of Applied Science program that provides a flexible 2+2+2 pathway for students from high school to a 4-year institution. The program?s CAE-CDE accreditation demonstrates that Columbus State is a national leader in cybersecurity education. Through the Information Technology Flexible Apprenticeship project (DUE 1902211), the college seeks to expand the cybersecurity program to provide experiential opportunities for students through an earn-and-learn model that has been widely successful at the college.

Additional information about this project and Columbus State's continued work with the Advanced Technological Education program can be found at: https://www.cscc.edu/awardprojects.
